Description: Round vessel, egg shaped. Fine ring base. Small opening on top and area where handle would have been attached. Whitish porous paste with fugitive light turquoise glaze, now largely flaked off.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

AP written on bottom, from EEF, so probably from the temenos of Apollo. Found with faience objects given by the EEF: Eg.Inv.3577 to Eg.Inv.3595 and 02.770, 72.1418, and 88.1003, P.725 to P.824, P.4418 to P.8145. The general shape of the flask is similar to one found in the Priests’ Quarter of Karnak. This specimen, made of an apple green-yellowish faience, is dated to the end of the 26th–early 27th dynasty (Anus, P. Sa’ad, R. 1971, ‘Habitations de prêtres dans le temple d'Amon de Karnak’, Kêmi XXI, 226, fig. 13).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (FA.15)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
